note_models.name: Cloze-88141
Cloze

fields: A {{c2::Western}} blot is used to analyze {{c1::protein}}

What type of probe is used to bind protein when using a Western blot? 

{{c1::Labeled antibody}}
binds protein that has been separated by gel electrophoresis and transferred to a membrane
The {{c1::Western}} blot is the confirmatory test for HIV after a positive ELISA
{{c1::Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA)}} is an immunologic test used to detect the presence of either a specific antigen or antibody in a patient's blood sample
major ELISA variations include direct, sandwich, and competitive; can have high sensitivity and specificity
When using ELISA, detection involves the use of an {{c1::antibody}} linked to an {{c2::enzyme}}

added substrate then reacts with enzyme, producing a detectable signal (e.g. color change)


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RRbuz3VQ100
{{c1::LTB4}} is an arachidonic acid pathway metabolite that causes neutrophil chemotaxis.

Which type of immunity (innate or adaptive) includes T cells and B cells? 

{{c1::Adaptive immunity}}

Which type of immunity (innate or adaptive) includes circulating antibodies? 

{{c1::Adaptive immunity}}

Which type of immunity (innate or adaptive) includes macrophages and monocytes? 

{{c1::Innate immunity}}

Which type of immunity (innate or adaptive) includes neutrophils and dendritic cells? 

{{c1::Innate immunity}}

Which type of immunity (innate or adaptive) includes NK cells? 

{{c1::Innate immunity}}
even though NK cells are derived from lymphoid precursors, they are still considered part of innate immunity

Which type of immunity (innate or adaptive) includes complement? 

{{c1::Innate immunity}}

Is innate immunity specific or nonspecific? 

{{c1::Non-specific}}

Does innate immunity have a memory response?

{{c1::No}}

Which type of immunity (innate or adaptive) occurs rapidly, over minutes to hours?

{{c1::Innate immunity}}

Which type of immunity (innate or adaptive) has limited diversity?

{{c1::Innate immunity}}

Is adaptive immunity specific or nonspecific? 

{{c1::Highly specific}}

Does adaptive immunity have a memory response?

{{c1::Yes}}

Which type of immunity (innate or adaptive) develops over long periods?

{{c1::Adaptive immunity}}

Which type of immunity (innate or adaptive) has extensive diversity?

{{c1::Adaptive immunity}}

Which type of immunity (innate or adaptive) includes physical barriers, such as skin and mucous membranes? 

{{c1::Innate immunity}}

Which type of immunity (innate or adaptive) includes physiologic barriers, such as temperature and pH? 

{{c1::Innate immunity}}

Which type of immunity (innate or adaptive) includes chemical barriers, such as lysozyme and defensins? 

{{c1::Innate immunity}}
The {{c2::idio}}-type of an antibody is determined by the {{c1::Fab}} region (Fc or Fab)
fragment, antigen binding; determines what antigen can be bound
The {{c2::iso}}-type of an antibody is determined by the {{c1::Fc}} region (Fc or Fab)
Constant region, Carboxy terminal; determines class (e.g. IgG, IgM, etc.)
The {{c1::heavy}} chain contributes to the Fab and Fc region of an antibody
The {{c1::light}} chain only contributes to the Fab region of an antibody

Which primary lymphoid organ is the site for immune cell production? 

{{c1::Bone marrow}}

Which primary lymphoid organ is the site of T-cell differentiation and maturation? 

{{c1::Thymus}}
The lymph node {{c2::paracortex}} contains {{c1::high endothelial venules (HEV)}}, through which T and B cells enter from the blood

homing receptors on lymphocytes, such as L selectins, bind to addressins present on HEVs 

Histologically, the endothelial cells at these sites are plump and cuboidal in shape rather than the flattened endothelial cells observed in other sites. These regions develop under the influence of cytokines released during antigen processing and presentation and the subsequent activation of lymphocytes. Evidence for this is that animals raised in a germ-free environment (essentially without any foreign antigen stimulus) fail to develop HEV.
The {{c1::thymus}} is an encapsulated lymphoid organ located in the anterosuperior mediastinum
The {{c1::cortex}} of the thymus is dense and comprised of {{c2::immature}} T cells
{{c1::Memory B}} cells are mature, differentiated B cells characterized by surface IgG, IgA, or IgE
{{c1::Major histocompatibility complexes (MHCs)}} present antigen fragments to T cells and bind T-cell receptors (TCRs)
Major histocompatibility complexes (MHCs) are encoded by {{c1::HLA}} genes

Which MHC class is associated with the gene products of HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C? 

{{c1::MHC I}}
"MHC 1 loci have 1 letter"

Which MHC class is expressed on all nucleated cells and platelets? 

{{c1::MHC I}}
not expressed on RBCs
MHC {{c2::I}} binds to the T-cell receptor (TCR) and CD-{{c1::8}}
rule of 8: MHC II * CD4 = 8; MHC I * CD8 = 8

Which MHC class is formed by 1 long chain and 1 short chain? 

{{c1::MHC I}}

Which MHC class has a smaller peptide binding groove (8 - 10 AA)? 

{{c1::MHC I}}

What protein is associated with MHC I? 

{{c1::β2-microglobulin}}

Which MHC class is associated with the gene products of HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR? 

{{c1::MHC II}}
"MHC 2 loci have 2 letters"

Which MHC class is expressed on antigen presenting cells (APCs), only? 

{{c1::MHC II}}

- e.g. B cells, macrophages, dendritic cells

- Bare lymphocyte syndrome is caused by defective expression of MHCII on APC surfaces
MHC {{c2::II}} binds to the T-cell receptor (TCR) and CD-{{c1::4}}
rule of 8: MHC II * CD4 = 8; MHC I * CD8 = 8

Which MHC class is formed by 2 equal length chains? 

{{c1::MHC II}}

Which MHC class has a larger peptide binding groove (13 - 17 AA)? 

{{c1::MHC II}}

What protein is associated with MHC II during synesthesis? 

{{c1::Invariant chain}}

How many classes of MHC I are expressed on a single cell?

{{c1::Six}}
three from each parent (codominant expression); the same is true for MHC II

Which CD marker(s) (CD4, CD8) does the T-cell express in the thymic cortex? 

{{c1::Both CD4 and CD8}}
also expresses the T-cell receptor (TCR) and CD3

Which CD marker(s) (CD4, CD8) does the T-cell express in the thymic medulla? 

{{c1::Either CD4 or CD8}}
also expresses the T-cell receptor (TCR) and CD3

Which type of selection allows survival of T cells expressing TCRs capable of binding self-MHC on cortical epithelial cells? 

{{c1::Positive selection}}

Where does positive selection of T cells occur? 

{{c1::Thymic cortex}}

Which type of selection causes T cells expressing TCRs with high affinity for self antigens on cortical epithelial cells to either undergo apoptosis or become regulatory T cells

{{c1::Negative selection}}
these antigens are tissue-restricted self-antigens;

Where does negative selection of T cells occur? 

{{c1::Thymic medulla}}

What non-nucleated cell expresses MHC class I? 

{{c1::Platelets}}
MHC {{c2::I}} presents {{c1::endogenously}} synthesized antigens to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells

Antigen loading onto MHC I occurs in the RER after breakdown of endogenous antigen by the {{c1::proteasome}} in the cytosol, and delivery to the RER via {{c2::TAP (transporter associated with antigen processing)}}

endogenous antigens are tagged by ubiquitin ligases for proteasomal degradation, then the cytosolic peptides are taken into the rough ER via the TAP whereupon they are loaded into nascent MHC1 molecules
MHC {{c2::II}} presents {{c1::exogenously}} synthesized antigens to CD4+ cytotoxic T cells
Antigen loading onto MHC II occurs following release of the {{c2::invariant chain}} in an {{c1::acidified endosome}}
The first signal for T-cell activation is binding between the {{c1::TCR}} and {{c1::MHC/peptide complex}}
e.g. antigen is presented on MHC II and recognized by TCR on CD4+ T cell
The second signal for T-cell activation is a costimulatory signal via interaction between {{c1::B7}} (APC) and {{c1::CD28}} (T cell)
note: B7 is also known as CD80/86
Differentiation of helper T cells to {{c2::Th2}} is inhibited by {{c1::IFN-γ (from Th1 cells)}}
Differentiation of helper T cells to {{c2::Th1}} is induced by {{c1::IFN-γ}} and {{c1::IL-12}}

Which type of antibody digestion results in 2 monovalent Fab regions and 1 Fc region? 

{{c1::Papain cleavage}}
cannot agglutinate antigen due to lack of bivalence
Ig{{c2::M}} exists as a {{c1::pentamer}} held by a J chain when secreted

How many identical antigens can a single IgM molecule bind?

{{c1::5}}
Not 10 because IgM has no hinge region and therefore no flexability, this results in steric hinderance

Does IgM fix complement?

{{c1::Yes}}

Which immunoglobulin is produced first in response to an infection?

{{c1::IgM}}

Which immunoglobulin is the main antibody produced during the primary response to antigen? 

{{c1::IgM}}
The {{c1::avidity}} of an antibody refers to the number of sites available to bind epitopes

Which immunoglobulin has the highest avidity? 

{{c1::IgM}}

In biochemistry, avidity refers to the accumulated strength of multiple affinities of individual non-covalent binding interactions, such as between a protein receptor and its ligand, and is commonly referred to as functional affinity.

Which immunoglobulin has the highest affinity? 

{{c1::IgG}}

Try to think about it as though you were measuring the intensity with which Velcro sticks to something fuzzy. The affinity is the strength with which one Velcro spike attaches to the object. The avidity is how strongly the whole piece of Velcro is capable of grabbing on

Which immunoglobulin is the main antibody produced during the secondary response to antigen? 

{{c1::IgG}}

What is the most abundant immunoglobulin isotype in serum?

{{c1::IgG}}

Does IgG fix complement?

{{c1::Yes}}

Does IgG cross the placenta? 

{{c1::Yes}}
provides infants with passive immunity

Which immunoglobulin(s) fix complement? 

{{c1::IgM and IgG}}

Which immunoglobulin(s) cross the placenta? 

{{c1::IgG}}
provides infants with passive immunity

Which immunoglobulin opsonizes bacteria? 

{{c1::IgG}}
also neutralizes bacterial toxins and viruses

Which immunoglobulin is the most produced antibody overall? 

{{c1::IgA}}
however, has lower serum concentration than IgG
IgA exists as a {{c1::monomer}} in circulation
Ig{{c2::A}} exists as a {{c1::dimer}} held by a J chain when secreted
IgA crosses epithelial cells by {{c1::transcytosis}}

Which immunoglobulin is produced in the GI tract and protects against gut infections? 

{{c1::IgA}}
e.g. Giardia

Which immunoglobulin is released into breast milk (colostrum)? 

{{c1::IgA}}

Which immunoglobulin is released into secretions (tears, saliva, mucus)? 

{{c1::IgA}}

Does IgA fix complement?

{{c1::No}}

Does IgA cross the placenta? 

{{c1::No}}
IgA is transported through the mucosa via binding between the {{c1::J chain}} of IgA and the {{c2::polymeric Ig}} receptor on epithelial cells
IgA dimers bind to pIgR found on basolateral surface of intestinal epithelial cells and undergoes transcytosis
When IgA is released into the mucosa, the poly Ig receptor becomes the {{c1::secretory component}}, which protects IgA from luminal proteases

As linked IgA dimer is released into intestinal lumen, a portion of pIgR remains attached (secretory component), which forms the complete secretory IgA molecule (protected from luminal enzymes by the secretory component)

thus oral vaccines will induce GI tract immunity
IgE cross-links when exposed to allergen, mediating type {{c1::I}} hypersensitivity reactions

- When multiple bound IgE on mast cells / basophils cross links a multivalent antigen, this pulls the FceRI (high affinity IgE receptor) together 

- clumping of many FceRI induces signalling that leads to degranulation

Which immunoglobulin contributes to immunity to worms by activating eosinophils?

{{c1::IgE}}

What is the least abundant immunoglobulin isotype in serum?

{{c1::IgE}}

Which immunoglobulin(s) can be secreted by plasma cells? 

{{c1::IgA, IgG, IgM or IgE (one type per plasma cell)}}

Which immune cell is a lymphocyte member of the innate immune system? 

{{c1::Natural killer (NK) cells}}

Which immunoglobulin typically mediates antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC)?

{{c1::IgG}}

IgE can mediate ADCC when the target is a parasitic worm 

The antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC), also referred to as antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity, is a mechanism of cell-mediated immune defense whereby an effector cell of the immune system actively lyses a target cell, whose membrane-surface antigens have been bound by specific antibodies.
Maternal IgG crossing the placenta is an example of {{c1::passive}} immunization

What part of an antigen should be preserved to elicit an immune response when given as an inactivated/killed vaccine? 

{{c1::Epitope}}
i.e. the precise region on the immunogen that interacts with the antibody

What is the first type of immunoglobulin produced in a neonate? 

{{c1::IgM}}
By age 1, the total IgA level is approximately {{c1::20}}% of adult levels
hence why breastfeeding is very important
A {{c1::hapten}} is a small antigen that may conjugate with larger proteins to elicit an immune response
e.g. penicillin may act as a hapten and bind to RBCs, causing immune hemolytic anemia
If O2 accepts one electron, it forms {{c1::superoxide (O2-)}}

What mitochondrial enzyme reduces superoxide (O2-) to H2O2? 

{{c1::Superoxide dismutase}}
{{c1::Toll-like receptors (TLRs)}} on cells of the immune system are activated by {{c2::pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs)}} that are commonly shared by microbes
examples of PAMPs include LPS (gram negative bacteria), flagellin (bacteria) and nucleic acids (viruses)

Are toll-like receptors (TLRs) found on cells of the innate or adaptive immune system?

{{c1::Both :)}}
i.e. both macrophages, dendritic cells, etc. AND lymphocytes
Toll-like receptor (TLR) activation results in upregulation of {{c1::NF-κB}}, a nuclear transcription factor that activates immune response genes
Complement may be activated via the {{c2::classic}} pathway, which is mediated by {{c1::IgM}} and {{c1::IgG}}
"GM makes classic cars"

What complement protein does the classical pathway of activation begin with? 

{{c1::C1}}
C1 activated by IgM or IgG bound to antigen
Complement may be activated via the {{c1::alternative}} pathway, which occurs spontaneously or when microbrial products activate complement

What complement protein does the alternative pathway of activation begin with? 

{{c1::C3}}
C3 activated spontaneously or by microbial products
Complement may be activated via the {{c2::lectin}} pathway, which is mediated by {{c1::mannose}} on microbial surfaces
complement may also be activated by other sugars on the microbe surface

What complement protein does the lectin pathway of activation begin with? 

{{c1::C1-like complex}}
All pathways of complement activation result in the production of {{c1::C3 convertase}}, which converts C3 to C3a and C3b

Which form of C3 convertase is produced via the alternative complement pathway? 

{{c1::C3bBb}}
All pathways of complement activation result in the production of {{c1::C5 convertase}}, which converts C5 to C5a and C5b

Which form of C5 convertase is produced via the lectin and classic complement pathways? 

{{c1::C4b2b3b}}

Which form of C5 convertase is produced via the alternative complement pathway? 

{{c1::C3bBb3b}}

Which complement proteins are part of the membrane attack complex (MAC)?

{{c1::C5b-C9}}
lyses microbes by creating a hole in the cell membrane

Which complement protein is a neutrophil chemotactic?

{{c1::C5a}}

Which complement protein is an opsonin for phagocytosis?

{{c1::C3b}}
During leukocyte rolling, {{c1::selectin}} "speed bumps" are upregulated on {{c2::endothelial}} cells
{{c2::E}}-selectin expression is induced by {{c1::IL-1}} and {{c1::TNF}}
{{c2::Selectins}} on endothelial cells bind {{c1::Sialyl-LewisX}} on leukocytes, resulting in rolling of leukocytes along the vessel wall
a similar interaction also occurs between GlyCAM-1 (endothelium) and CD34 (leukocytes)
{{c1::ICAM-1}} and {{c1::VCAM-1}} are cellular adhesion molecules that are upregulated on endothelium during leukocyte adhesion
also referred to as CD54 (ICAM-1) and CD106 (VCAM-1)
{{c2::Cellular adhesion molecules (CAMs)}} on endothelial cells bind {{c1::integrins}} on leukocytes, resulting in firm adhesion to the vessel wall
specifically, ICAM-1 binds to CD11/18 integrins and VCAM-1 binds to VLA-4 integrin
Integrin expression is upregulated on leukocytes by {{c1::C5a}} and {{c2::LTB4}}
Neutrophil chemotactants include bacterial products, {{c1::IL-8}}, {{c2::C5a}}, and {{c3::LTB4}}
other chemotactants include kallikrein and platelet-activating factor
Destruction of phagocytosed material occurs through {{c2::respiratory (oxidative) burst}}, which utilizes {{c1::O2}} as a substrate
O2 is converted to {{c2::superoxide (O2-)}} by the enzyme {{c1::NADPH oxidase}} (oxidative burst)
O2- is converted to {{c1::H2O2}} by the enzyme superoxide dismutase (oxidative burst)
H2O2 is converted to {{c1::HClO- (hypochlorite)}} by the enzyme {{c2::myeloperoxidase}} (oxidative burst)
HClO- (hypochlorite) may also be referred to as bleach

Which immunodeficiency is characterized by inability to generate HClO- (hypochlorite) from H2O2? 

{{c1::Myeloperoxidase deficiency}}
{{c1::Lactoferrin}} is a protein found in secretory fluids and neutrophils that inhibits microbrial growth via {{c2::iron chelation}}
Almost all pathogens have an absolute requirement for iron, thus iron restriction inhibits growth of most pathogens.
DiGeorge syndrome is a developmental failure to develop the {{c1::3rd}} and {{c1::4th}} pharyngeal pouches
DiGeorge syndrome is characterized by {{c1::decreased}} number of T cells
thus have recurrent viral and fungal infections

Which complement proteins are decreased in C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency? 

{{c1::C4 and C2}}
C1-inhibitor regulates the C1 complex, thus unregulated C1 complex consumes lots of C4 and C2 to make C3 convertase (C2b4b)

Which complement deficiencies result in increased risk for Neisseria infection? 

{{c1::Terminal Complement (C5-C9) Deficiencies}}
- MAC is the main defense against neisseria
Early Complement Deficiencies (C1-C4) are characterized by increased risk of severe, recurrent pyogenic {{c1::sinopulmonary::location}} infections

- specifically, increased risk of pneumococcal and h. flu pneumonia

- this begins in infancy
Deficiency of early {{c1::complement}} proteins are associated with SLE
e.g. C1q, C4, and C2 (due to impaired ability to clear Ag/Ab complexes)

Which immune cell has the cell surface protein CD28? 

{{c1::T cells}}

Which immune cell has the cell surface protein CD16 and CD56? 

{{c1::NK cells}}
Each B cell produces light chains that are either {{c1::kappa}} or {{c1::lambda}}
- this is typically produced in a ratio of 3:1 in a given sample of tissue
Tumor cells can evade apoptosis / immune surveillance by downregulating expression of {{c1::MHC class I}} or alternative splicing of the {{c2::Fas}} receptor

- Thus Immunodeficiency (both primary and secondary) increases risk for cancer; alternative splicing of the Fas receptor splices out transmembrane domain converting it to a soluble form not expressed on cell surface

- this is an example of the cancer hallmark: evasion of apoptosis
IFN-y is important for activating the {{c1::respiratory burst}} in phagocytes

The respiratory burst is important because it allows phagocytes the ability to kill ingested microbes

Steps 1 & 2 are the Respiratory Burst, step 3 converts the product to HClO- (the most potent antibacterial - H2O2 is still antibacterial), this distinguishes CGD from a Myeloperoxidase Deficiency (nitro blue tetrazolium test)
A direct ELISA tests for an {{c1::antigen}}, whereas the indirect ELISA tests for an {{c2::antibody against an antigen}}

In which type of immunity (innate or adaptive) is microbial resistance not heritable?

{{c1::Adaptive immunity}}

In which type of immunity (innate or adaptive) does microbial resistance persist through generations?

{{c1::Innate immunity}}
This does NOT change within a organism's lifetime

Which type of immunity (innate or adaptive) utilizes C-Reactive Protein and Complement?

{{c1::Innate immunity}}

The complement system is a part of the immune system that enhances (complements) the ability of antibodies and phagocytic cells to clear microbes and damaged cells from an organism, promote inflammation, and attack the pathogen's cell membrane.

C-reactive protein (CRP) is an annular (ring-shaped), pentameric protein found in blood plasma, whose circulating concentrations rise in response to inflammation.
LPS, bacterial flagellin, and viral nucleic acids are detected by the innate immune system via {{c1::Pattern-Recognition}} Receptors
Differentiation of helper T cells to {{c2::Th17}} is inhibited by {{c1::IFN-y}} and {{c1::IL-4}} (from Th1 and Th2 cells)

What acute phase reactant is upregulated during inflammation to opsonize targets, fixing complement and facilitate phagocytosis?

{{c1::C-reactive protein}}

What acute phase reactant can be measured clinically as a nonspecific sign of ongoing inflammation?

{{c1::C-reactive protein}}
The {{c1::inflammasome}} is a cytoplasmic protein complex that recognizes products of dead cells, microbial products, and crystals
- inflammasome leads to increased IL-1B / IL-18 production which leads to inflammatory response (neutrophilic recruitment and invasion)
Activation of the inflammasome leads to increased production of {{c1::IL-1B}} and IL-18
the inflammasome cleaves pro-IL-1B/18 to their active forms
C3bBb is naturally unstable and dissociates. {{c1::Properdin}} binds to C3bBb and stabilizes it.

{{c1::C1 inhibitor (C1INH)}} is a major regulator of classic pathway activation. {{c1::C1INH}}
binds to {{c2::C1r}} and {{c2::C1s}} causing them to dissociate from {{c2::C1q}}.
Decay accelerating factor (DAF, CD55) acts to dissociate{{c1::C4b2b (C3 convertase)}} resulting in loss of enzymatic activity and inhibition of the {{c2::classical}} and {{c2::lectin}} pathways.
{{c1::Factor I}} with co-factor help from {{c2::CD46 }} cleaves {{c3::C4b}} following the dissociation of {{c3::C4b2b}} by DAF.
{{c1::Factor H}} competes with {{c2::Factor B}} for binding to surface bound {{c2::C3b}}. Additionally; {{c1::Factor H}} can disassociate {{c3::C3bBb}} complexes.
{{c1::Anaphylatoxin inactivator}} or {{c2::serum carboxypeptidase B}} removes the {{c3::terminal arginine residues}} from {{c4::anaphylatoxins (C3a, C4a, and C5a)}} resulting in their inactivation.
{{c1::Vitronectin (S protein)}} binds to the C567 complex preventing insertion of the MAC into the membrane, thus preventing cytolysis
{{c1::CD59}} binds {{c2::C5b-8 complexes}} and prevents {{c2::C9}} polymerization

{{c1::Type I Hereditary angioedema}} is caused by deficiency in {{c2::C1 esterase inhibitor.}} Leads to {{c3::spontaneous edema formation in various tissues}} – can lead to {{c4::asphyxiation and death if in larynx.}}
{{c1::HLA-1}} molecules are presented by {{c2::everyone}} while {{c1::HLA-2}} molecules are only presented by {{c2::antigen presenting cells }}
{{c1::HLA-1}} molecules are a {{c2::monomers (with B2 micoglobulin)}} while {{c1::HLA-2}} molecules are {{c2::dimers }}
{{c3::CD1}} functions similarly to {{c1::HLA-2}} with a structure similar to {{c1::HLA-1}}; it presents {{c2::lipid antigens}} and may activate {{c4::CD4+}}, {{c4::CD8+}} or {{c4::NK cells}}
Precursor T cells that express neither CD4 nor CD8 and are called {{c1::double negative (DN) cells}}
Located in the thymus

{{c3::Double negative (DN) cells}} begin to express the genes for {{c1::RAG-1 and RAG-2 (recombinase-activating genes 1 and 2)}} which are responsible for {{c2::randomly rearranging the genes that encode the alpha, beta and gamma chains of the T cell antigen receptor (TCR).}}

{{c1::The Double Negative T cell}} that productively rearrange the {{c2::B chain}} will express it on its surface with an invariant molecule {{c3::pre-Talpha}} along with {{c3::CD3}} and {{c3::zeta}}. Together they make up the {{c4::pre-T cell receptor}} and the cell is now called a pre-T cell.
DiGeorge syndrome is a developmental failure to develop the {{c1::thymus}}
Negative co-stimulatory interactions of T cells include the binding of accessory molecules {{c1::PD-L1 (on APC)}} to {{c2::PD-1 (on T cell)}} and {{c3::B7 (on APC)}} to {{c4::CTLA-4 (on T cell).}}
PD-L1/PD-1 binding strongly inhibits T cells and induces Treg differentiation. This interaction is essential for maintaining peripheral tolerance and for limiting the immune response.

{{c1::CD3}} is a chaperone for the {{c2::TCR}} – transporting newly synthesized {{c2::TCR molecules}} to the cell surface. It also functions as a {{c3::cellular signaling molecule via transmembrane and cytoplasmic domains}}
Activation of a {{c1::CD4+ T helper cell}} includes the transcription of {{c2::IL-2 and IL-2 receptor genes}}. {{c2::IL-2}} is an {{c3::autocrine growth factor for T cells}}

About 48 hours following the initial recognition event of TCR binding HLA class II + exogenously processed antigen, the T cells become enlarged lymphoblasts, enter G1 phase of the cell cycle and begin to undergo repeated rounds of cell division. This proliferation (entering the cell cycle) eventually leads to differentiation.

Upon initial activation, it is thought that all T helper cells can be classified as {{c1::T-helper-0 (Th0)}}. These are a precursor to the {{c2::Th1}}, {{c2::Th2}}, and {{c2::Th17}} phenotypes and produce cytokines - {{c3::IL-2}}, {{c4::IL-4}}, and {{c5::IFN-gamma}}
Antigen stimulation of Th0 CD4+ T cells in the presence of specific cytokines {{c1::IFN-gamma}} and {{c2::IL-12}} drive T cells toward the {{c3::Th1 subset.}}
Initially, the source of IL-12 is from the APC and IFN-gamma is initially from natural killer cells, gamma-delta TCR+ T cells or from dendritic cells.
Activated Th0 cell will convert to a {{c1::Th1 cell}}  and produce {{c2::IFN-gamma}} and {{c3::IL-2}}. This is known as a {{c4::type 1 immune response}}

Cytokines of type 1 immune response activate
1. {{c1::Natural killer cells}}
2. {{c2::Cytotoxic T cells}}
3. {{c3::Macrophages to become more phagocytically active}}
4. {{c4::Other Th1 cells to proliferate and become more active}}
5. {{c5::B cells to undergo the isotype switch and produce certain
subclasses of IgG (usually IgG3)
}}
When Th0 CD4+ T cells are stimulated with antigen in the presence of {{c1::IL-4,}} and {{c3::IL-10}} {{c2::Th2 cells}} develop.
The initial source of IL-4 early in driving the CD4+ Th0 cell to a Th2 phenotype is usually the mast cell certain types of dendritic cells or certain NK cell subsets.
T-helper-2 (Th2) - produce {{c1::IL-4}}, {{c2::IL-5}}, {{c3::IL-10}} and {{c4::IL-13.}}

The cytokines influence an isotype switch in B cells to IgG1, IgG2, IgG4, IgA and IgE and assist in the activation of other Th2 cells and recruitment of granulocytes such as eosinophils and basophils.
IL-4, IL-5, IL-10 and IL-13 influence {{c1::antibody-mediated or “humoral” immune responses}} – a.k.a., {{c2::type 2 immune responses.}}
When Th0 CD4+ T cells are stimulated with antigen in the presence of {{c1::IL-6,}} {{c1::IL-1B}} and {{c1::IL-21}}, {{c2::Th17 cells}} develop
The initial source of Il-1 and IL-6 in driving the CD4+ Th0 cell to a Th17 phenotype are APCs
T-helper-17 (Th17) - produce {{c1::IL-17}}, {{c2::IL-21}}, and {{c3::IL-22}}

Additionally IL-21 produced by Th17 cells acts in a positive feedback loop to stimulate the differentiation of Th0 cells to Th17 cells.

Th17 cells produce cytokine IL-17 which is found in autoimmune diseases including, rheumatoid arthritis, multiple sclerosis, and psoriasis and is important in gut inflammation.
T-regulatory (Tregs) – produce {{c1::TGF-B}}, {{c2::IL-10}} and {{c3::IL-4.}} They function to {{c4::regulate the autoimmune response and limit damaging host responses to foreign antigens.}}
Tregs specific for self-antigens can develop in the thymus (natural Tregs) or Tregs specific for self- or foreign- antigens can develop outside the thymus (induced Tregs).

{{c1::RIG-I-like receptors (RLRs)}} are a family of receptors that are critical for {{c2::immune responses to viruses}}. This family of receptors binds to {{c3::double stranded RNA}} from RNA viruses resulting in the production of {{c4::type I interferons.}}
{{c1::Scavenger receptors}} recognize anionic polymers and acetylated low density lipoproteins expressed by certain {{c3::pathogens}} as well as {{c2::old and dying host cells.}}
Recognition and binding of these ligands by scavenger receptors on a phagocyte, leads to their removal.
{{c1::Phosphatidyl serine (PS)}} is presented on apoptic cells to {{c2::scavenger receptors}} on macrophages to and induce {{c3::phagocytosis}}

PS is a phospholipid on the inner leaf of the plasma membrane. When a host cell undergoes programmed cell death – “apoptosis”, PS becomes exposed on the surface of the cell and can be bound by macrophages that have PS receptors (PSR) which triggers the phagocyte to engulf the cell undergoing apoptosis.

There are two cellular systems involved in the process of phagocytosis– {{c1::the myeloid granulocyte system}} and the {{c2::mononuclear system}}. The cellular components of either system can be considered "professional phagocytes".

Basophils (granules stain with basic dyes) are found in the {{c1::circulation (normally ~1% or less of all leukocytes)}} but the tissue based version is the {{c2::mast cell}}. Mostly, these cells kill pathogens {{c3::extracellularly}} by {{c3::releasing granule contents onto the surface of a pathogen without phagocytosis.}}

eosinophils (granules stain with acid dyes, e.g. eosin) – are found in the circulation (normally ~1-2% of all leukocytes) and like basophils appear to mostly kill pathogens {{c1::extracellularl}}y by {{c2::releasing granule contents on the surface of a pathogen without phagocytosis.}}

Foreign-derived substances such as {{c1::bacterial lipopolysaccharides}}, {{c2::n-formyl methionyl peptides}} (or {{c3::f-Met-Leu-Phe}}), and {{c4::certain bacterial cell wall components}} exert {{c5::potent chemotactic influence}}

Both lipopolysaccharide and f-Met-Leu-Phe are unique to bacteria. This provides a simple specific signal for the presence of bacteria towards which phagocytes will move. These substances fall into the category of pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs).

Host molecules that are chiefly responsible for opsonization include

1. {{c1::Complement component 3b (C3b)}}
2. {{c2::The Fc region of certain classes of antibody, especially IgG1 and IgG3}}
3. {{c3::Fragments of acute phase proteins, for example C-reactive protein}}
Two enzymatic pathways produce nitric oxide (NO) via oxidation of {{c1::L-arginine}} - the {{c2::constitutive NO synthase (cNOS}}) and the {{c3::inducible NO synthase (iNOS)}}.
Phagocytes have both enzymes, but predominantly use the iNOS to kill ingested pathogens, tumor cells, etc..
iNOS is “inducible” in the presence of {{c1::Tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNFa)}}, {{c2::gIFN}} and some microbial products such as {{c3::LPS}}
The products of iNOS and, in particular, NO, inhibit {{c1::iron-sulfur-dependent enzymes}}, {{c2::damages DNA}}, {{c3::membrane phospholipids}}, etc. of many pathogens

NO also mediates a variety of biological reactions for the host. iNOS is under strict regulatory control by cytokines. It can also damage host components as we have seen above in the superoxide pathway.
Nitric oxide (iNOS pathway) and super oxide anion (respiratory burst pathway) may interact to form a highly active molecule called {{c1::peroxynitrite.}}
{{c3::C-reactive protein}} is synthesized only in the liver in response to {{c1::IL-1}} and {{c2::IL-6}}

Cleavage of CRP by enzymes from neutrophils produces peptides that opsonize, enhance complement fixation, and promote chemotaxis. Elevated CRP has also been shown to be a reliable marker of unstable coronary artery disease – an inflammatory disease.
A read-out of the induction of acute phase proteins is the {{c1::erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).}}
Tight binding (a.k.a. “arrest” or “firm adhesion”) – is initiated under the influence of {{c1::chemokines}}.

Chemokines can be either cell bound on endothelial cells or secreted locally by inflammatory cells. Classical examples are the neutrophil chemoattractant IL-8 and the macrophage chemokine called macrophage inflammatory protein-1 (MIP-1). Other chemoattractant molecules contribute significantly to this process (e.g. C5a, C3a, bacterial products, etc.).

The adhesion molecules involved in homing of effector lymphocytes have been termed {{c1::vascular addressins}} because they direct extravasation of different populations of lymphocytes to {{c2::particular lymphoid}} and even {{c2::non-lymphoid organs}}
– that is, to the correct vascular “address”.

T lymphocytes and other mononuclear cells possessing the receptor {{c1::LPAM-1 (aka integrin alpha 4 beta 7)}} will bind to {{c2::MAdCAM-1 ligand}} on {{c3::endothelial cells lining the vasculature that feeds a mucosal site.}}

This directs such T cells to specifically home into and extravasate at mucosal sites (ie. MALT). Presumably, this ensures that during the activation of effector cells during a primary response and memory cells during a secondary response, a lymphocyte will home to the site where it is most likely to encounter the antigen it recognizes.

Unlike effector lymphocytes which are known to specifically traffic or home to specific sites, naïve lymphocytes tend to {{c1::randomly migrate amongst the secondary lymphoid tissue}} using adhesion molecules found on {{c2::all HEVs}}
Presumably, this is done in an attempt to increase the possibility that the lymphocyte will encounter its antigen in the lymph nodes or spleen.

{{c1::matrix metalloproteinases}} can regulate the action of cytokines and growth factors by converting them from {{c2::latent to active}} form or in some cases {{c3::degrading cytokines so that they become inactive.}}
